msIdentifier.collection: John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts

msContents.summary: This manuscript is an early fifteenth-century Book of Hours, written in Latin in the Netherlands. Many leaves are now missing, probably with illuminations, but several leaves with historiated initials and floral borders remain at major divisions. The text has an unusual two-column layout.

msItem.title: Book of Hours, Use of Utrecht

supportDesc.extent: ii+122+iii; 148 x 103 mm bound to 150 x 110 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Intermittent modern foliation in pencil, upper or lower right recto

collation.p: Structure uncertain; leaves missing before fol. 1, after fols. 5, 6, 14, 15, 25, 29, 54, 83, 85, 105, 115

layoutDesc.layout: Two columns of twenty-two lines; frame-ruled in red ink with double upper and lower bounding lines; written area: 97 x 74 mm

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Gothic--textualis semi-quadrata; responses, versicles, and antiphons written in smaller script

decoDesc.decoNote: Twelve historiated initials and a one-column miniature of the Annunciation (fol. 64v); floral borders at major text divisions; one-line and two-line blue initials with red penwork flourishing and gold initials with blue penwork flourishing alternating throughout, with simple repeating extensions along the full length of the left edge of the text column
10vHistoriated initial S, John the Baptist with a lamb
[66r]Historiated initial C, Saint Catherine of Alexandria
89rHistoriated initial D, two souls in Hell

binding.p: Eighteenth-century vellum cover; "Heures du XIVe Siecle" written in ink on spine

history.provenance: William Hargrave Dawson (born 1878), of Titlington Hall, Northumberland; John Frederick Lewis, Philadelphia; given by his widow, Anne Baker Lewis, to the Free Library of Philadelphia in 1936
